metadata.title: Artificial Intelligence Basics
metadata.content: AI is the simulation of human intelligence in machines.

metadata.title: Machine Learning Applications
metadata.content: Machine learning powers recommendation systems, fraud detection, and autonomous vehicles.

metadata.title: Natural Language Processing
metadata.content: NLP enables computers to understand, interpret, and generate human language.

metadata.title: Computer Vision Systems
metadata.content: Computer vision allows machines to identify objects and people in images and videos.

metadata.title: Reinforcement Learning
metadata.content: Reinforcement learning is training algorithms using rewards and punishments.

Thanks for reading. I hope this inspired you!

Now stop dawdling, and go build something!

By the way, I used Site Stats Database to find the above sites (there are tons more I didn't share).

I sorted by highest traffic change from March 2024-April 2025 to find sites that are crushing it on Google AFTER the 2024 March Core update, which was the nail in the coffin for most content sites.

I updated Site Stats Database yesterday, adding 51,000+ new sites AND monthly traffic data up to April 2025 (and beginning Sept 2023).

Not only does the database include the traffic data, it even includes the % change in traffic between every month, so you can easily sort and filter to find winning sites after any Google update!

SSDB is by far the largest database of its kind, with extensive data for over 510,000 sites in every niche imaginable.

I use it to find low competition niches, winning sites, and even link building opportunities. It’s a ridiculously powerful tool. Read more about it here if you’re curious: sitestatsdb.com

832,000 monthly visitors, and the site was only launched in June of 2023. Less than two years ago.

I’d guestimate monthly revenue to be around $10,000-$15,000 (the site is monetized with ads).

If that’s not inspiring, I don’t know what is!

So yeah, not impossible to build a giant, data-rich directory like EpisodeHive, even if you don’t know how to code.

Oh yeah, about EpisodeHive…

Here’s the traffic:

If you want more proof that it’s possible to build a site like this as a non-developer, allow me to present InTheTap.com.

Mike (@NicheDown), who isn’t a developer, built it with Cursor in several weeks. It’s got TONS of data on tap water all across the US. The level of detail for each location is wild.

This obviously isn’t just a simple content site that anyone could build. But, it’s certainly possible to build something like this using AI if you don’t know how to code.

It would not be too difficult to replicate this site using an IDE like Cursor or Windsurf.

Successful niche site #3: EpisodeHive .com

This site has lots of data about TV shows. Such as user reviews, which they use to produce pages like “The Best Episodes of [TV Show]”.

Pretty smart strategy, using data to produce unique content in the massive niche of TV shows.

So yeah, anyone can do this for better or worse lol.

Now… given CreativeKidsColor’s traffic, what’s their revenue like?

My estimate is $3,000-$5,000/month. The site is monetized with Journey by Mediavine ads.

Not half bad for a 7-month old site (yes, the domain was registered on 9/13/2024)!

The low DR of just 1.5 indicates that this is a very low competition niche.

But, before you go start your own coloring page site, keep in mind copyright issues. You’d need permission or a licensing deal to make branded coloring pages. I don’t know if this site got permission or not. But if not, they’ll likely face some legal issues soon.

So, to avoid copyright issues, stick with non-branded coloring pages. They may be a bit more competitive, but you won’t have the prospect of a lawsuit looming over your head.

And by the way, don’t worry if you don’t know how to make a coloring page. I certainly don’t have the skills, and yet I made this in less than a minute with ChatGPT:

Each PDF targets a secondary keyword. For example, “hello kitty merry christmas coloring page” and “christmas hello kitty coloring page”.

Very smart strategy.

And it’s paying off big time. This site’s traffic trajectory is mouth-watering.

Successful niche site #2: CreativeKidsColor .com

This site provides topical coloring page PDFs for free. There are 80 posts on the site in total, so it’s not huge. However, each post includes dozens of different coloring pages.

Accounting Insights is monetized with Mediavine ads. Based on some rough napkin math, they’re likely earning $10,000-$15,000/mo if SimilarWeb’s numbers are to be believed.

Accounting is a high value niche, so it could easily be more.

65K monthly visitors from Google according to Ahrefs. Likely underestimated.

SimilarWeb shows much higher numbers.

Most of that traffic is from the US. And 70% of it is from organic search.

If I were shown this site and asked to guess its traffic, I’d guess 0 from Google (maybe thousands a month from Bing/Yahoo/DDG, though). This is the type of site that got destroyed by Google’s 2023 “Helpful Content Update”.

Boy, would I be wrong.

Apparently, Google loves this site.

Successful niche site #1: AccountingInsights .org

It’s boring, it’s drab, but it’s simple and profitable.

What I find crazy is that it’s a typical niche site, à la 2018. It looks like it’s straight outta the golden age of niche sites.

100% pure content site.

Heavy keyword targeting.

No attempt at demonstrating EEAT.

Tons of simple articles without imagery, graphs, or anything fancy. Just keyword-rich headings and walls of text.

I found a bunch of niche sites that are absolutely CRUSHING it on Google right now.

Including a 7-month old site with 198,000 monthly visitors.

Niche sites aren't dead.

If you have a hard time believing me, keep reading. I was pretty shocked by some of these.

🧵...

The site is: qwertychamp.com

If you create an account, you can see your typing stats and join the leaderboard.

100% free to use.

What features should I add?

I used Cursor to "vibe code" a simple, customizable typing test website.

You can:

- Select the difficulty level
- Customize the text
- Set a custom test duration
- Set a custom test word count

Also, there's a leaderboard. See if you can beat my high score!
@Meta @facebook

Thanks for reading. I hope this inspired you!

Now stop dawdling, and go build something!

By the way, I used Site Stats Database to find the above sites (there are tons more I didn't share).

I sorted by highest traffic change from March 2024-April 2025 to find sites that are crushing it on Google AFTER the 2024 March Core update, which was the nail in the coffin for most content sites.

I updated Site Stats Database yesterday, adding 51,000+ new sites AND monthly traffic data up to April 2025 (and beginning Sept 2023).

Not only does the database include the traffic data, it even includes the % change in traffic between every month, so you can easily sort and filter to find winning sites after any Google update!

SSDB is by far the largest database of its kind, with extensive data for over 510,000 sites in every niche imaginable.

I use it to find low competition niches, winning sites, and even link building opportunities. It’s a ridiculously powerful tool. Read more about it here if you’re curious: sitestatsdb.com

832,000 monthly visitors, and the site was only launched in June of 2023. Less than two years ago.

I’d guestimate monthly revenue to be around $10,000-$15,000 (the site is monetized with ads).

If that’s not inspiring, I don’t know what is!

So yeah, not impossible to build a giant, data-rich directory like EpisodeHive, even if you don’t know how to code.

Oh yeah, about EpisodeHive…

Here’s the traffic:

If you want more proof that it’s possible to build a site like this as a non-developer, allow me to present InTheTap.com.

Mike (@NicheDown), who isn’t a developer, built it with Cursor in several weeks. It’s got TONS of data on tap water all across the US. The level of detail for each location is wild.

This obviously isn’t just a simple content site that anyone could build. But, it’s certainly possible to build something like this using AI if you don’t know how to code.

It would not be too difficult to replicate this site using an IDE like Cursor or Windsurf.

Successful niche site #3: EpisodeHive .com

This site has lots of data about TV shows. Such as user reviews, which they use to produce pages like “The Best Episodes of [TV Show]”.

Pretty smart strategy, using data to produce unique content in the massive niche of TV shows.

So yeah, anyone can do this for better or worse lol.

Now… given CreativeKidsColor’s traffic, what’s their revenue like?

My estimate is $3,000-$5,000/month. The site is monetized with Journey by Mediavine ads.

Not half bad for a 7-month old site (yes, the domain was registered on 9/13/2024)!

The low DR of just 1.5 indicates that this is a very low competition niche.

But, before you go start your own coloring page site, keep in mind copyright issues. You’d need permission or a licensing deal to make branded coloring pages. I don’t know if this site got permission or not. But if not, they’ll likely face some legal issues soon.

So, to avoid copyright issues, stick with non-branded coloring pages. They may be a bit more competitive, but you won’t have the prospect of a lawsuit looming over your head.

And by the way, don’t worry if you don’t know how to make a coloring page. I certainly don’t have the skills, and yet I made this in less than a minute with ChatGPT:

Each PDF targets a secondary keyword. For example, “hello kitty merry christmas coloring page” and “christmas hello kitty coloring page”.

Very smart strategy.

And it’s paying off big time. This site’s traffic trajectory is mouth-watering.

Successful niche site #2: CreativeKidsColor .com

This site provides topical coloring page PDFs for free. There are 80 posts on the site in total, so it’s not huge. However, each post includes dozens of different coloring pages.

Accounting Insights is monetized with Mediavine ads. Based on some rough napkin math, they’re likely earning $10,000-$15,000/mo if SimilarWeb’s numbers are to be believed.

Accounting is a high value niche, so it could easily be more.

65K monthly visitors from Google according to Ahrefs. Likely underestimated.

SimilarWeb shows much higher numbers.

Most of that traffic is from the US. And 70% of it is from organic search.

If I were shown this site and asked to guess its traffic, I’d guess 0 from Google (maybe thousands a month from Bing/Yahoo/DDG, though). This is the type of site that got destroyed by Google’s 2023 “Helpful Content Update”.

Boy, would I be wrong.

Apparently, Google loves this site.

Successful niche site #1: AccountingInsights .org

It’s boring, it’s drab, but it’s simple and profitable.

What I find crazy is that it’s a typical niche site, à la 2018. It looks like it’s straight outta the golden age of niche sites.

100% pure content site.

Heavy keyword targeting.

No attempt at demonstrating EEAT.

Tons of simple articles without imagery, graphs, or anything fancy. Just keyword-rich headings and walls of text.

I found a bunch of niche sites that are absolutely CRUSHING it on Google right now.

Including a 7-month old site with 198,000 monthly visitors.

Niche sites aren't dead.

If you have a hard time believing me, keep reading. I was pretty shocked by some of these.

🧵...

The site is: qwertychamp.com

If you create an account, you can see your typing stats and join the leaderboard.

100% free to use.

What features should I add?

I used Cursor to "vibe code" a simple, customizable typing test website.

You can:

- Select the difficulty level
- Customize the text
- Set a custom test duration
- Set a custom test word count

Also, there's a leaderboard. See if you can beat my high score!
@Meta @facebook

My estimate is $3,000-$5,000/month. The site is monetized with Journey by Mediavine ads.

Not half bad for a 7-month old site (yes, the domain was registered on 9/13/2024)!

The low DR of just 1.5 indicates that this is a very low competition niche.

But, before you go start your own coloring page site, keep in mind copyright issues. You’d need permission or a licensing deal to make branded coloring pages. I don’t know if this site got permission or not. But if not, they’ll likely face some legal issues soon.

So, to avoid copyright issues, stick with non-branded coloring pages. They may be a bit more competitive, but you won’t have the prospect of a lawsuit looming over your head.

And by the way, don’t worry if you don’t know how to make a coloring page. I certainly don’t have the skills, and yet I made this in less than a minute with ChatGPT:

Each PDF targets a secondary keyword. For example, “hello kitty merry christmas coloring page” and “christmas hello kitty coloring page”.

Very smart strategy.

And it’s paying off big time. This site’s traffic trajectory is mouth-watering.

Successful niche site #2: CreativeKidsColor .com

This site provides topical coloring page PDFs for free. There are 80 posts on the site in total, so it’s not huge. However, each post includes dozens of different coloring pages.

Accounting Insights is monetized with Mediavine ads. Based on some rough napkin math, they’re likely earning $10,000-$15,000/mo if SimilarWeb’s numbers are to be believed.

Accounting is a high value niche, so it could easily be more.

65K monthly visitors from Google according to Ahrefs. Likely underestimated.

SimilarWeb shows much higher numbers.

Most of that traffic is from the US. And 70% of it is from organic search.

If I were shown this site and asked to guess its traffic, I’d guess 0 from Google (maybe thousands a month from Bing/Yahoo/DDG, though). This is the type of site that got destroyed by Google’s 2023 “Helpful Content Update”.

Boy, would I be wrong.

Apparently, Google loves this site.

Successful niche site #1: AccountingInsights .org

It’s boring, it’s drab, but it’s simple and profitable.

What I find crazy is that it’s a typical niche site, à la 2018. It looks like it’s straight outta the golden age of niche sites.

100% pure content site.

Heavy keyword targeting.

No attempt at demonstrating EEAT.

Tons of simple articles without imagery, graphs, or anything fancy. Just keyword-rich headings and walls of text.

I found a bunch of niche sites that are absolutely CRUSHING it on Google right now.

Including a 7-month old site with 198,000 monthly visitors.

Niche sites aren't dead.

If you have a hard time believing me, keep reading. I was pretty shocked by some of these.

🧵...

The site is: qwertychamp.com

If you create an account, you can see your typing stats and join the leaderboard.

100% free to use.

What features should I add?

I used Cursor to "vibe code" a simple, customizable typing test website.

You can:

- Select the difficulty level
- Customize the text
- Set a custom test duration
- Set a custom test word count

Also, there's a leaderboard. See if you can beat my high score!
